prior_works.title: Abandoning Objectives: Evolution Through the Search for Novelty Alone
prior_works.role: Introduced novelty search as a primary driver of open-ended discovery, formalizing novelty as an explicit objective and using archives to encourage continual exploration.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s definition of open-endedness through novelty explicitly builds on the core idea from novelty search that progress can be measured by behavioral novelty rather than fixed task reward.

prior_works.title: Illuminating Search Spaces by Mapping Elites (MAP-Elites)
prior_works.role: Established quality-diversity optimization, balancing diversity (novelty) with competence, and maintaining repertoires of skills indexed by behavior descriptors.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The position paper’s novelty–learnability lens echoes MAP-Elites’ dual emphasis on discovering diverse behaviors that are also performant/learnable, grounding their formalization in QD methodology.

prior_works.title: POET: Paired Open-Ended Trailblazer
prior_works.authors: Rui Wang, Joel Lehman, Jeff Clune, Kenneth O. Stanley, et al.
prior_works.role: Pioneered open-ended co-evolution of environments and agents, using transfer and minimal criteria to ensure problems are novel yet solvable.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: POET operationalizes the paper’s ‘novelty plus learnability’ criteria by generating novel tasks that remain within a learnable frontier, directly informing the proposed blueprint for open-ended systems.

prior_works.title: Autocurricula and the Emergence of Innovation from Social Interaction
prior_works.authors: Yannic B. Leibo, Edward Hughes, Marc Lanctot, et al.
prior_works.role: Provided a theory and evidence that multi-agent interaction yields self-generated curricula and escalating innovation (open-endedness) via competitive and cooperative dynamics.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The argument that open-endedness is essential for ASI leverages autocurricula as a mechanism for unbounded capability growth, a view explicitly developed in this work (co-authored by one of the position paper’s authors).

prior_works.title: Formal Theory of Creativity, Fun, and Intrinsic Motivation (1990–2010)
prior_works.role: Formalized learning progress/compressibility improvement as an intrinsic objective, linking novelty with learnability via the notion of what is interesting because it becomes learnable.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s learnability dimension traces to intrinsic-motivation theory, where progress (not mere surprise) defines valuable novelty—directly aligning with their novelty-and-learnability formalization.

prior_works.title: On the Opportunities and Risks of Foundation Models
prior_works.authors: Rishi Bommasani, Drew A. Hudson, Ehsan Adeli, et al.
prior_works.role: Codified the foundation model paradigm, documenting their generality, transfer, and broad safety implications.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The proposal to implement open-ended systems atop foundation models—and to foreground their safety implications—builds on this conceptualization of FMs as generally-capable, safety-critical substrates.

prior_works.title: Voyager: An Open-Ended Embodied Agent with Large Language Models
prior_works.role: Demonstrated LLM-driven lifelong skill discovery and autonomous curriculum generation in Minecraft via tool use, self-reflection, and skill libraries.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Voyager provides concrete evidence that foundation models can support open-ended, self-improving agents, validating the paper’s path toward open-ended systems built on top of FMs.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s core contribution—a formal, operational view of open-endedness as the joint pursuit of novelty and learnability, and a roadmap to realize it atop foundation models—stands on three intertwined lineages. First, novelty-centric search from Lehman and Stanley established novelty as an explicit progress signal, while quality-diversity methods like MAP-Elites showed how to pair diversity with competence via repertoires. POET unified these ideas into an open-ended algorithm that co-evolves tasks and agents, explicitly enforcing that newly generated challenges are both novel and solvable through transfer—an instantiation of the paper’s novelty–learnability axis. Second, intrinsic motivation theory, especially Schmidhuber’s formalization of learning progress, gives the theoretical grounding for ‘learnability’: novelty is valuable to the extent it becomes compressible/learnable, anticipating the paper’s emphasis on human-relevant, discoverable fronts. Third, multi-agent work on autocurricula (Leibo et al.) explains mechanisms that generate unbounded innovation via interaction, supporting the claim that open-endedness is essential for sustained capability growth toward ASI.
Building on these foundations, the paper argues that foundation models now supply the representational breadth, transfer, and tooling to scale open-ended systems. Bommasani et al. frame FMs’ generality and safety stakes, while Voyager provides a concrete exemplar of LLM-based, open-ended skill acquisition. Together, these works directly enable the paper’s thesis: with novelty-and-learnability principles, autocurricula dynamics, and FM substrates, open-ended, ever-improving AI is both feasible and safety-critical.
